title: Heat Storage 1B: Heat storage depends on specific heat
subtitle: Why do some materials take longer to heat up or cool down than others?
about:
How much heat is stored in an object depends on its specific heat, as
described by the formula below:



| *Q* = <font color="red">***c*<sub>p</sub>***m*(*T*<sub>final</sub>-*T*<sub>initial</sub>) </font>

 |
{: cellpadding="10" border="0" bgcolor="#ffffff"}

This model is similar to 1A, except that the specific heats of the two
rectangular objects are different.

1.  Run the model and note the temperatures measured by the two
    thermometers.
2.  Turn the graph on to watch the changes of the temperatures.
3.  Use the buttons at the upper-right corner of the graph window to
    rescale the curves if necessary.
4.  Wait until the temperatures of the two objects do not change any
    further.
5.  Record the final temperature of the two objects in your workbook.

**Click the Reset button** and change the specific heats of the two
objects using the drop-down menus below the model. Repeat steps 1-5 for
two more different setups. Make sure that the specific heats are
different in each setup.
